column2: commonly known as the NATO phonetic alphabet or the ICAO phonetic alphabet
column3: is the most widely used radiotelephone spelling alphabet. The ITU phonetic alphabet and figure code is a variant.

column2: the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) assigned codewords acrophonically to the letters of the English alphabet
column3: so that letters and numbers would have distinct names that would be most easily understood by those who exchange voice messages by radio or telephone
column4: regardless of language differences or the quality of the communication channel. Such spelling alphabets are often called "phonetic alphabets"
column5: but they are unrelated to phonetic transcription systems such as the International Phonetic Alphabet.

column1: The 26 code words in the spelling alphabet are assigned to the 26 letters of the English alphabet in alphabetical order as follows: Alfa
column2: Bravo
column3: Charlie
column4: Delta
column26: Zulu.Strict adherence to the prescribed spelling words—including the apparently misspelled "Alfa" and "Juliett"—is required in order to avoid the problems of confusion that the spelling alphabet is designed to overcome. A 1955 NATO memo stated that:

column1: It is known that [the ICAO spelling alphabet] has been prepared only after the most exhaustive tests on a scientific basis by several nations. One of the firmest conclusions reached was that it was not practical to make an isolated change to clear confusion between one pair of letters. To change one word involves reconsideration of the whole alphabet to ensure that the change proposed to clear one confusion does not itself introduce others.
After the phonetic alphabet was developed by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) (see history below) it was adopted by many other international and national organizations
column2: including the International Telecommunication Union (ITU)
column3: the International Maritime Organization (IMO)
column4: the United States Federal Government (as Federal Standard 1037C: Glossary of Telecommunications Terms
column7: both of which cite Joint Publication 1-02: Department of Defense Dictionary of Military and Associated Terms
column8: but modifying the spelling of alfa and juliett) and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
column9: and the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU)
column11: the Association of Public-Safety Communications Officials-International (APCO); and by many military organizations such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the now-defunct Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO).

column1: The same alphabetic code words are used by all agencies
column2: but each agency chooses one of two different sets of numeric code words. NATO uses the regular English numeric words (Zero
column3: One
column4: with some alternative pronunciations)
column5: whereas the ITU (beginning on 1 April 1969) and the IMO define compound numeric words (Nadazero
column7: Bissotwo…). In practice these are used very rarely
column8: as they frequently result in confusion between speakers of different languages.

column1: A spelling alphabet is used to spell parts of a message containing letters and numbers to avoid confusion
column2: because many letters sound similar
column3: for instance "n" and "m" or "f" and "s"; the potential for confusion increases if static or other interference is present. For instance the message "proceed to map grid DH98" could be transmitted as "proceed to map grid Delta-Hotel-Niner-Ait". Using "Delta" instead of "D" avoids confusion between "DH98" and "BH98" or "TH98". The unusual pronunciation of certain numbers was designed to reduce confusion as well.

column1: In addition to the traditional military usage
column2: civilian industry uses the alphabet to avoid similar problems in the transmission of messages by telephone systems.  For example
column3: it is often used in the retail industry where customer or site details are spoken by telephone (to authorize a credit agreement or confirm stock codes)
column4: although ad-hoc coding is often used in that instance. It has been used often by information technology workers to communicate serial or reference codes (which are often very long) or other specialised information by voice. Most major airlines use the alphabet to communicate passenger name records (PNRs) internally
column6: with customers. It is often used in a medical context as well
column7: to avoid confusion when transmitting information.

column1: Several letter codes and abbreviations using the spelling alphabet have become well-known
column2: such as Bravo Zulu (letter code BZ) for "well done"
column3: Checkpoint Charlie (Checkpoint C) in Berlin
column4: and Zulu Time for Greenwich Mean Time or Coordinated Universal Time. During the Vietnam War
column5: the U.S. government referred to the Viet Cong guerrillas and the group itself as VC
column6: or Victor Charlie; the name "Charlie" became synonymous with this force.

column1: The final choice of code words for the letters of the alphabet and for the digits was made after hundreds of thousands of comprehension tests involving 31 nationalities. The qualifying feature was the likelihood of a code word being understood in the context of others. For example
column2: football has a higher chance of being understood than foxtrot in isolation
column3: but foxtrot is superior in extended communication.The pronunciation of the code words varies according to the language habits of the speaker. To eliminate wide variations in pronunciation
column4: recordings and posters illustrating the pronunciation desired by the ICAO are available. However
column5: there are still differences in pronunciation between the ICAO and other agencies
column6: and the ICAO has conflicting Latin-alphabet and International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) transcriptions. Also
column7: although all codes for the letters of the alphabet are English words
column8: they are not in general given English pronunciations.

column1: Pronunciations are somewhat uncertain because the agencies
column2: while ostensibly using the same pronunciations
column3: give different transcriptions
column4: which are often inconsistent from letter to letter. The ICAO gives a different pronunciation for IPA transcription and for respelling
column5: and the FAA also gives different pronunciations depending on the publication consulted
column8: or the ATC manual (§ 2-4-16). The Alliance for Telecommunications Industry Solutions (ATIS) gives English spellings
column9: but does not give pronunciations or numbers. The ICAO
column11: and FAA use modifications of English numerals
column13: while the ITU and IMO compound pseudo-Latinate numerals with a slightly different set of modified English numerals
column14: and with stress on each syllable. Numbers 10–99 are spelled out (that is
column15: 17 is spoken "one seven" and 60 is spoken "six zero")
column16: while for hundreds and thousands the English words hundred and thousand are used.The pronunciation of the digits 3
column19: and 9 differs from standard English – being pronounced tree
column22: and niner. The digit 3 is specified as tree so that it is not pronounced sri; the long pronunciation of 4 (still found in some English dialects) keeps it somewhat distinct from for; 5 is pronounced with a second "f" because the normal pronunciation with a "v" is easily confused with "fire" (a command to shoot); and 9 has an extra syllable to keep it distinct from German nein 'no'.Only the ICAO prescribes pronunciation with the IPA
column23: and then only for letters. Several of the pronunciations indicated are slightly modified from their normal English pronunciations: [ˈælfa
column34: partially due to the substitution of final schwas with the [ɑ] vowel. Both the IPA and respelled pronunciations were developed by the ICAO before 1956 with advice from the governments of both the United States and United Kingdom
column35: so the pronunciations of both General American English and British Received Pronunciation are evident
column36: especially in the rhotic and non-rhotic accents. The respelled version is usually at least consistent with a rhotic accent ('r' pronounced)
column42: whereas the IPA version usually specifies a non-rhotic accent ('r' pronounced only before a vowel)

column1: Prior to World War I and the development and widespread adoption of two-way radio that supported voice
column2: telephone spelling alphabets were developed to improve communication on low-quality and long-distance telephone circuits.

column1: The first non-military internationally recognized spelling alphabet was adopted by the CCIR (predecessor of the ITU) during 1927. The experience gained with that alphabet resulted in several changes being made during 1932 by the ITU. The resulting alphabet was adopted by the International Commission for Air Navigation
column2: the predecessor of the ICAO
column3: and was used for civil aviation until World War II. It continued to be used by the IMO until 1965.

column2: many nations used their own versions of a spelling alphabet. The U.S. adopted the Joint Army/Navy radiotelephony alphabet during 1941 to standardize systems among all branches of its armed forces. The U.S. alphabet became known as Able Baker after the words for A and B. The Royal Air Force adopted one similar to the United States one during World War II as well. Other British forces adopted the RAF radio alphabet
column3: which is similar to the phonetic alphabet used by the Royal Navy during World War I. At least two of the terms are sometimes still used by UK civilians to spell words over the phone
column4: namely F for Freddie and S for Sugar.

column4: in 1943 the CCB (Combined Communications Board; the combination of US and UK upper military commands) modified the U.S. military's Joint Army/Navy alphabet for use by all three nations
column5: with the result being called the US-UK spelling alphabet. It was defined in one or more of CCBP-1: Combined Amphibious Communications Instructions
column7: and CCBP-7: Combined Communication Instructions. The CCB alphabet itself was based on the U.S. Joint Army/Navy spelling alphabet. The CCBP (Combined Communications Board Publications) documents contain material formerly published in U.S. Army Field Manuals in the 24-series. Several of these documents had revisions

column2: the U.S. military conducted significant research into spelling alphabets. Major F. D. Handy
column3: directorate of Communications in the Army Air Force (and a member of the working committee of the Combined Communications Board)
column4: enlisted the help of Harvard University's Psycho-Acoustic Laboratory
column5: asking them to determine the most successful word for each letter when using "military interphones in the intense noise encountered in modern warfare.". He included lists from the US
column12: and that of the International Telecommunications Convention. According to a report on the subject:

column1: The results showed that many of the words in the military lists had a low level of intelligibility
column2: but that most of the deficiencies could be remedied by the judicious selection of words from the commercial codes and those tested by the laboratory. In a few instances where none of the 250 words could be regarded as especially satisfactory
column3: it was believed possible to discover suitable replacements. Other words were tested and the most intelligible ones were compared with the more desirable lists. A final NDRC list was assembled and recommended to the CCB.

column16: the non-English spellings Alfa and Juliett are used. Alfa is spelled with an f as it is in most European languages because the English and French spelling alpha would not be pronounced properly by native speakers of some other languages – who may not know that ph should be pronounced as f.  Juliett is spelled with a tt for French speakers
column17: because they may otherwise treat a single final t as silent. Some published versions incorrectly list "alpha" and "juliet" – presumably because of the use of spell checker software – but those spellings are never correct and should be changed back to "alfa" and "juliett" wherever such mistakes are found.Defined by various international conventions on radio
